New Records: The Dodgers' 8-0 win in Game 4 was the most lopsided shutout win in postseason history, one run better than Game 5 of the 1965 World Series against the Twins.
Key Match Events: The road team has scored first and homered in the top of the first inning in all four games so far.
Gavin Lux’s two-run home run in the seventh to cap the scoring.

Chris Taylor started in centerfield in Game 4, swapping positions twice, with Hernández moving to the outfield in the third inning with Michael Kopech on the mound, then back to third base in the sixth with Evan Phillips pitching.
Pre-Game Insights: The Dodgers and Padres will play a winner-take-all Game 5 of their National League Division Series on Friday night at Dodger Stadium, with the winner hosting the Mets in the NLCS two days later.
Post-Match Reflections: Wednesday night’s win at Petco Park in San Diego was the Dodgers’ first road playoff victory since Game 5 of the 2021 NLDS in San Francisco, snapping a seven-game postseason skid while wearing the road grays.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Dodgers are 10-6 in winner-take-all games in the postseason, including 5-3 during this current run of 12 playoff appearances in a row.
Others: Kiké Hernández got the start at third base in Game 4, and was 2-for-4, giving him eight different postseasons with the Dodgers in which he started a game, along with 2015-20 and 2023. That matched Justin Turner (2015-22) for the most such years in Dodgers franchise history.
